Yes.  I was underscoring the tendency for discussion communities
to oversimplify models, leading to the assumption that if one is
talking about idempotence in methods, then one must be talking
about REST.  It's another example of lumping HTTP and REST
into a single lump.  As one learns these patterns, it takes continued
effort and review to keep the lumps from bleeding together.

Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Roy T. Fielding" <fielding@...>
To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
Cc: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, January 24, 2003 1:12 PM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Nifty REST T-Shirts


> > I noticed that while idempotence seems an important
> > distinguishing property of some HTTP methods, it's not
> > mentioned at all in REST.  Or did I miss it?
> 
> The reason it is important to HTTP/1.1 is for pipelining requests
> and knowing when it should be safe to repeat the same request without
> user intervention.  The only part where I briefly touch on it is when
> mentioning Waldo's paper on partial failures in RPC systems.
> 
> ....Roy
>
